title: Classification, Sentiment Analysis, and Topic Modeling using Cloud Based APIs
description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one. 

This workshop provides and overview of cloud based, hosted APIs that provide generalized, hosted document classification, sentiment analysis, and topic modeling functionality.  Participants will learn how to submit an API request to a pre-trained machine learning or generative AI model, read results for a text document, and evaluate the output.  

This workshop is part of a broader series covering programming for the digital humanities, with an emphasis on document and text analysis. Although these workshops do not have any formal prerequisites, some background in Python and SQL would be helpful. These workshops will build on material from previous sessions, so it is recommended but not requred to take the workshops in sequence. 

Registration Links: 

  • Data Analysis with Python and SQL, Part 1:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12900575
  • Data Analysis with Python and SQL, Part 2:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901228
  • Reading Data from APIs with Python:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901233
  • Image, Audio, and Video to Text Transcription with Python:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901235
  • Python Background for Text Analysis and Natural Language Processing:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901494
  • Document Classification and Sentiment Analysis using Python and Scikit-Learn
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901511
  • Document Topic Modeling with Python
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901514
  • Classification, Sentiment Analysis, and Topic Modeling using Cloud Based APIs:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901513

Note: This workshop will be offered online through UCSF Zoom and in person at the UCSF Famri Library at Mission Bay. All registrants will recieve an email from libcal with location information and a Zoom link prior to the start of the workshop. You will have the option to attend in person or online regardless of how you register, so please just select the option you think is most likely at the time of registration.

title: Data Science Help Desk
description:
Visit our virtual data science help desk! 

Introducing the Data Science Help Desk, a place to ask your general questions about data science including how to download software or code packages, prep for upcoming data science classes, get started with programming, connect with data science expertise, and more. No appointments required, just walk/drop in!

How does the Data Science Help Desk work?

At the Data Science Help Desk, we can answer general data science questions and connect you with a wealth of data science resources and expertise. The Help Desk is hosted by graduate student TAs of the Data Science Team twice a week on Tuesdays and Wednesdays from 2-3 pm subject to change to fit the needs of the UCSF community. The Data Science Help Desk is open to the UCSF community including faculty, staff, and trainees.

We look forward to meeting you at the Data Science Help Desk!

 

Access Help Desk: Zoom Link

title: 3D Printing Part 1: Intro to 3D Printing
description:
Are you curious about the applications for 3D printing at UCSF?

Join Makers Lab staff for the first pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D printing and how the technology can be used in the health sciences.  

After attending the 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. List the main components of a 3D printer
  2. Identify four methods for obtaining 3D models
  3. Recognize which is the ideal 3D printer for your project
  4. Generate a print time estimate for a given 3D model
  5. Execute a 3D print from start to finish

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Sharing, Versioning, and Collaborating with Git and Github
description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California and Cal State affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one. 

This workshop will introduce Git and GitHub, two widely used tools for archiving, versioning, and collaborating on code and other documents. 

The session will cover how to use Git and GitHub for version control, including creating repositories, committing changes, and tagging releases. You’ll also explore how GitHub can be used to share your projects, collaborate with other developers, and create tutorials and simple web sites to present your work. 

This workshop will not use Unix to interact with Git and does not have any prerequisites. Instead, we will use the GitHub web interface and focus primarily on how to create a repository and portfolio for sharing and presenting your work, including code created with Jupyter Notebook. 

Note - The UC carpentry workshop series (back in October) offered a session on Git and Github using Unix. If you missed the software carpentry session and/or would like to watch a recording of a previous UCSF LIbrary github workshop with a greater focus on Unix, please see the recording on the CLE at: 

https://courses.ucsf.edu/course/view.php?id=5208

title: 3D Printing Part 2: Intro to 3D Modeling
description:
Recommended prerequisite: 3D Printing Part 1

Want to create your own models to 3D print in the Makers Lab?

Join Makers Lab staff for the second pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D design & modeling using the web-based application Tinkercad. This pop-up is for beginners, but all skills levels are welcome to attend.

After attending the 90-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Design a basic 3D model in Tinkercad
  2. Export a model out of Tinkercad for 3D printing
  3. Locate resources for continuing your learning with Tinkercad
  4. Identify other 3D design & modeling software for more advanced projects

Make sure to sign up for a Tinkercad account before the pop-up and use a three-button if you have one available. You don't even need to download Tinkercad, it is a free, web-based application that you can use anywhere, as long as you have an internet connection.

Need to design 3D models with more complex geometries? Attend an upcoming Fusion 360 pop-up! Unsure if Tinkercad is the right software for your project? Contact the Makers Lab for suggestions.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Needlecraft Monthly Meet-Up
description:
Calling all fans of knitting, crochet, cross-stitch, sewing, and embroidery!

This virtual meet-up is a chance for beginning and experienced UCSF crafters to come together and work on their projects in a fun and relaxed atmosphere. We hang, we chat, we work on fabulous projects, and share advice and inspiration. Join us!

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. See all upcoming Needlecraft Meet-Ups to save your seat today!

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, please contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Photo from meetup host and UCSF staff member Ariel

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: 3D Printing Part 3: 3D Printing from Medical Imaging
description:
Recommended prerequisite: 3D Printing at UCSF Part 1

Do you have a CT scan you would like to convert to a 3D print?

Join Makers Lab staff to start creating 3D printable models from CT scans. Note: this pop-up will focus on converting and 3D printing models of bone. Learn how 3D printing is helping to improve medical education, research, and patient education.

We encourage attendees to use their own laptops and download the 3D Slicer software prior to the pop-up, available for free for Mac and Windows. A three-button mouse is recommended, but not required. De-identified DICOM files (CT scan) will be provided at the start of the pop-up.

After attending the 90-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Segment bone from a CT scan using a free medical image viewer
  2. Create a 3D surface rendering from a CT scan
  3. Prepare an STL file for 3D printing

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.
